A ring homomorphism $\varphi: R \longrightarrow R'$ is called an isomorphism if it admits an inverse, i.e., there exists a ring homomorphism $\psi: R' \longrightarrow R$ such that $\psi \circ \varphi=\mathrm{id}_{R}$ and $\varphi \circ \psi=\mathrm{id}_{R'}$. This is equivalent to $\varphi$ being bijective.

The dihedral group $D_{n}$, for $n \geq 3$, is the group of symmetries (rotations and reflections) of a regular (convex) $n$-gon. It is generated by the permutations $\sigma = (1, \ldots, n)$ and $\tau = \left(\begin{array}{ccccc}1 & 2 & 3 & \ldots & n \\ 1 & n & n-1 & \ldots & 2\end{array}\right)$.
Does the concept of a/an Ring Isomorphism need to be defined for a definition of a/an Dihedral Group to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The definition of a Dihedral Group involves the concept of group theory, specifically focusing on the symmetries of polygons which include rotations and reflections. These operations form a group under the operation of composition, and the group is defined by generators and relations among these generators.

On the other hand, a Ring Isomorphism pertains to the field of ring theory, a branch of abstract algebra dealing with rings, which are algebraic structures equipped with two binary operations satisfying certain properties. A ring isomorphism is a specific type of function between two rings that preserves the ring operations and is bijective, establishing a fundamental equivalence between the two rings.

The concept of a ring and ring isomorphism is unrelated to the definition of a dihedral group, which is purely within the realm of group theory and does not involve the structure or properties of rings. Therefore, understanding or defining a ring isomorphism is not necessary for defining or understanding a dihedral group.
